section.title: Introduction
section.para: This document specifies the XDI protocol bindings for the exchange of operations on XDI graphs via XDI messages. The XDI 1.0 Core specification defines the XDI graphs and the XDI Messaging specification defines the messaging patterns and the messages themselves.

Transport bindings may be based on a client/server model or on other network topologies. The XDI Messaging concepts of "target graph", "message envelope", "message", "operation", as well as the logic performed by the XDI processor, remain independent of a transport binding.

section.title: XDI Direct Binding
section.para: The XDI Direct Binding defines a mechanism by which XDI message envelopes are transmitted using HTTP POST messages.

section.title: HTTP Considerations
section.para: When exchanging XDI messages using HTTP 1.1, HTTP headers should be used to ensure both requester and responder

section.title: Serialization
section.para: The XDI Core specification defines several serialization formats for XDI messages. It is thus important for requesters and responders to agree on a common serialization format when exchanging a set of XDI messages.

The following rules apply:
Both HTTP requesters and responders SHOULD set the Content-Type HTTP header to indicate the serialization format used for the XDI message.
The XDI/JSON serialization format (MIME type: application/xdi+json) MUST be supported by both requesters and responders. Other serialization formats MAY be supported.
An HTTP requester MAY set the Accept header to indicate what serialization formats it would prefer the HTTP responder uses.

section.title: Other
section.para: Beyond serialization, the following rules apply:

listitem.para: An HTTP requester SHOULD set the Content-Length HTTP header to indicate the length of the serialized XDI message contained in the request. This is especially useful if the HTTP requester does not support HTTP 1.1.

HTTP 1.1 requesters SHOULD use the chunked transfer encoding mechanism (Transfer-Encoding: chunked). Note that even if this mechanism is used, it is recommended to also include the Content-Length HTTP header.
HTTP responders SHOULD set HTTP headers for Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS).

section.title: Security Considerations
section.para:
This binding relies on message-level integrity protection via signing of the XDI messages as defined in the XDI Signatures specification .
Additionally, the Security Mechanisms specification protection of XDI messages in transit between requester and responder .

section.title: Error Reporting
section.para: In addition to the status codes defined in HTTP 1.1 , an HTTP responder SHOULD convey second-level error in the body of the message.

section.title: Example of an XDI Message Exchange Using the XDI Direct Binding
section.para:
The following is an example of an XDI request message.
POST /xdi/ HTTP/1.1 Host: demo.xdi.org Content-Type: application/xdi+json; charset=utf-8 Content-Length: 267
<< XDI/JSON serialized request here >>

The following is an example of an XDI response message (success case).
HTTP/1.1 200 OK Content-Type: application/xdi+json Content-Length: 202
<< XDI/JSON serialized response here >>

section.title: XDI Browser Binding
section.para: The browser binding defines a mechanism by which XDI requests are transmitted using a browser and an HTML Form.

section.title: XDI Artifact Binding
section.para: The artifact binding defines a mechanism by which XDI requests are transmitted using an artifact.
